question: Should the use of child performers be banned?

content.source_1: UN Committee on the Rights of the Child, General Comment No. 17 (2013) on Article 31 (The right of the child to rest, leisure, play, recreational activities, cultural life and the arts) — Affirms children’s right to participate in cultural and artistic life, while obligating states to protect them from economic exploitation and unsafe conditions; supports a regulate-and-protect approach rather than a blanket ban.
content.source_2: BBC News, “France votes to ban child beauty pageants,” 18 Sept 2013 — Reports that the French Senate approved a ban on beauty contests for children under 16 to combat hypersexualisation and protect minors, illustrating a policy choice to prohibit certain child performance contexts outright.
content.source_3: California Department of Industrial Relations, “Child Labor Laws — Entertainment Industry” (ongoing guidance; includes Coogan Law references, Family Code §§6750–6753) — Details strict limits on minors’ work hours, mandatory on-set education, permits, and trust accounts to safeguard earnings; evidence that robust regulation is used in lieu of prohibition.
content.source_4: Variety, “Dan Schneider Apologizes After ‘Quiet on Set,’ Addresses Allegations of Toxic Behavior at Nickelodeon,” March 2024 — Coverage of allegations about unsafe and exploitative environments for child TV performers; critics argue existing safeguards failed in practice, bolstering calls for far tighter restrictions or even bans in certain formats.
content.source_5: France: Loi n° 2020-1266 du 19 octobre 2020 visant à encadrer l’exploitation commerciale de l’image d’enfants de moins de seize ans sur les plateformes en ligne — Establishes permits, earnings escrow, and takedown/erasure rights for under-16 “kidfluencers,” showing governments are moving to fill protection gaps in newer performance arenas rather than prohibiting participation altogether.
content.source_6: U.S. Supreme Court, Joseph Burstyn, Inc. v. Wilson, 343 U.S. 495 (1952) — Recognizes motion pictures as protected speech under the First Amendment; a categorical ban on child performers would raise significant constitutional concerns in the U.S., indicating that narrowly tailored regulation is more legally viable than prohibition.
